name: Hyperphosphatemic Familial Tumoral Calcinosis (HFTC)
chief_complaint: Painful, hard lumps near my joints that keep growing
symptoms: Recurrent skin ulcers over calcified deposits
physical_findings: Erythema and warmth over affected areas
prognosis: Chronic progressive course with significant morbidity from recurrent calcifications and joint destruction. Early intervention may slow progression but complete remission is rare.
description: HFTC is an extremely rare autosomal recessive disorder of phosphate metabolism caused by mutations in FGF23, GALNT3, or KLOTHO genes. It leads to ectopic calcification in soft tissues, particularly periarticular regions, due to impaired phosphate excretion and abnormal FGF23 signaling. Lesions often begin in childhood and progressively worsen, causing severe functional impairment.
risk_factors: Certain ethnic backgrounds (reported higher in Middle Eastern populations)
